text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- A Bulgarian chartered aircraft with 150 passengers and eight-member crew on a flight from Beirut to Varna was hijacked on Tuesday afternoon by a Palestine terrorist 10 minutes before landing. The passangers were released at the Varna airport.
The terrorist demanded a passage to Oslo but after negotiations with the pilot he agreed to land in Varna and release the passangers. After refueling the plane took off for Oslo at 18:08 local time.
-- Bulgaria's air traffic controllers said they postponed a planned one-hour warning strike on Tuesday due to the hijack of the Bulgarian plane.

-- Bulgaria's Socialist party nominated late last night the culture minister Ivan Marazov and deputy foreign minister Irina Bokova as the party's new candidates for the presidential elections due on October 27.
The Supreme Court blocked on Monday the presidential candidacy of the party's initial nominee Georgi Pirinski because he was born in the U.S.

-- Japan has said it could extend a $300 million credit for upgrading of Bulgaria's largest oil refinery Neftohim but details of the deal are yet to be negotiated, Industry Minister Lyubomir Dachev said.
-- Bulgaria's August monthly inflation is expected around 15 percent and cumulative inflation for the first eight months about 109.1 percent, National Statistics Institute preliminary data shows.
-- Bulgaria's cabinet doubled tobacco's minimum purchasing prices in a bid to stimulate producers, cabinet official said.
-- The Privatisation Agency is expected to approve today the sale of 75 percent stake in the debt-ridden Plama oil refinery, initially slated for liquidation, to Bulgaria's Euroenergy holding.
-- Bulgaria's cabinet approved the sale of 67 percent of the five-star Sheraton Sofia Hotel Balkan to the South Korea's giant Daewoo Corp for $22.3 million in cash.
The cabinet also approved the sale of 55 percent of the Lovech-based Eltos electric tool maker to the Germany's Sparky Trading GmbH for 11.5 million German marks.

-- The Supreme court is expected to overrule today the Central Electoral Commission's decision to refuse registration to the main anti-communist opposition nominees for country's presidential elections.
-- Bulgaria is expected to launch by mid-September a scheme for bank privatisation, central bankers told International Monetary Fund's mission leader Ann McGuirk.

-- The International Monetary Fund will extend to Bulgaria the next $115 million tranche under a funding agreement signed in July only if the cabinet's structural reform programme is fully implemented, Ann McGuirk said. -- Sofia Newsroom, 359-2-84561
